body:
Hi there,

thanks for the report. Do you have a public sample page where this issue is occuring?

Thanks!
Max

I cann't find a public page now. but is simple to create a test.json file in current path

``` json
{ "hello": "世界" }
```

and run 

`python -mSimpleHTTPServer 1234`

then 

`curl localhost:1234/test.json`

> @cortesi: What's the purpose of `netlib.utils.cleanBin`, called by `ViewRaw`? I'm no console expert, so what is meant by `to make it safe to display` ?

Hello. I hope you don't mind me butting in here.

I looked at the source. "safe to display" in this case means replacing anything that isn't a valid printable ASCII character with a '.'.

In other words, the program is assuming that the console can only display 7 bit ASCII characters, (and TAB and NEWLINE if 'fixspacing' is true.) and anything else (e.g. UTF-8) is undisplayable binary 'junk', and is therefore filtered.

This is the correct filter for ASCII.

UTF-8 is a super-set of ASCII (as are most encoding types) so filtering everything to ASCII is a suitable 'lowest common denominator that will display everywhere (but without the extended characters being available!)

To reliably support other character sets, you should use a filter appropriate to 'charset' returned in the 'Content-Type:" header - with the additional caveat that the users terminal is set to handle that character set.

You 'need' (i.e. 'should have') a server-side filter to ensure that data that is illegal in the required character set is stripped (just as the 'cleanBin' function mentions above does for ASCII)

The more complete way to do this would be to use the iconv library, which can filter many character sets and even convert them automatically to the users local set.

Just feed it the remote document with the input charset (extracted from the "Content-type:") and the users local charset (determined from the users environment) - setting iconv to strip / replace invalid data rather than abort with a translating error.

This will then automatically convert (and sanatize) the input charset to the users required charset.

The 'quick fix' aluded to here (i.e. disable the 'cleanBin' filter) basically assumes that both the users charset is the same (or a superset) of the documents charset, and that the document contains no invalid encoding data.

It would sorta work most of the time, if a users terminal is set to UTF-8, and the remote document is ASCII or UTF-8, AND (a big one) the remote document character encoding is valid.

But it's really an unreliable hack..... There's a reason 'cleanBin' exists in the first place :-)

N.B. I've never used the python iconv bindings, so can't comment on them specifically.

https://www.gnu.org/software/libiconv/

https://pypi.python.org/pypi/iconv/1.0

Cheers,
 Jamie

Thanks for the explanations, Jamie!

Looks like this won't be much fun. However, converting everything to unicode should be sufficient for urwid to handle everything else: http://urwid.org/manual/encodings.html That being said, this is probably not our top priority at the moment. We'd love to see a pull request from the community for this.

Maximilian Hils notifications@github.com wrote:

> Thanks for the explanations, Jamie!

No problem! I've been battling with console character sets and control characters ever since I first started using a (real) DEC VT220 many years ago!

> Looks like this won't be much fun. However, converting everything to unicode should be sufficient for urwid to handle everything else: http://urwid.org/manual/encodings.html That being said, this is probably not our top priority at the moment. We'd love to see a pull request from the community for this.

Looks fun to me! Not fun for me is coding a MITM proxy for SSL, so it's just as well we're all different :-)

I looked at the Urwid link.... nice! Yes, it seems once you've sorted out what comes from the server, urwid will deal with the client-side (which is often the more trickier to diagnose, because users don't always have their setup configured properly, use all sorts of different console emulators, on all sorts of different platforms, and generally neglect to mention something important when complaining!)

I can understand how it's not a critical enhancement..... I'd have a go, but I've never programmed in Python (time to learn? :-) )

However, the originally suggested hack of simply not using the cleanBin function, and just passing everything through raw may be a good initial compromise - especially for those debugging something that they know will be using the same character encoding as their console is configured to use, and they trust the source not to spew out malicious control character codes etc.... usual caveats apply!

....but if you do, make it a non-default "only use if you understand the implications etc." option !

Actually, for UTF-8 at least (and all other character sets that are a superset of ASCII) you could still filter out the control characters below 32 -- just allow it to accept above 127

Cheers, Jamie

For some reason, github thought my last paragraph was quoted text. Not sure if you got it, but I wrote: " Actually, for UTF-8 at least (and all other character sets that are a superset of ASCII) you could still filter out the control characters below 32 -- just allow it to accept above 127"

Sorry to keep spamming, but I just noticed that mitmproxy forces a UTF console - not sure why, as as you point out, it seems urwid deals with that side of things...:

Mitmproxy:

```
    spec = ""
    for i in ["LANG", "LC_CTYPE", "LC_ALL"]:
        spec += os.environ.get(i, "").lower()
    if "utf" not in spec:
        print >> sys.stderr, "Error: mitmproxy requires a UTF console environment."
        print >> sys.stderr, "Set your LANG enviroment variable to something like en_US.UTF-8"
        sys.exit(1)
```

Thanks for the reference - maybe I should have said (without looking at the code) "urwid _can_ deal with that"

I have a horrible temptation to attempt a go at this issue...

@mhils Sorry to bother you from an ancient issue. 

This issue was closed last September, but non-ascii contents are still unicode-encoded in JSON view with mitmproxy 0.17.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1430856/15844547/ceac8e58-2c9d-11e6-936b-e5636638e786.png)

Is there a switch or something to turn `ensure_ascii` off? Or it's currently impossible?

Currently impossible; could be implemented, but I'd highly recommend against it, because of all the nasty things you can do with Unicode (see zalgo, for example).  If you trust that what you're viewing is not going to do anything nasty, you can edit the raw body, and (assuming your editor is vim) then run

```
:%!python -c 'import json, sys; print(json.dumps(json.load(sys.stdin), sort_keys=True, indent=4, ensure_ascii=False).encode("utf-8"))'
```
I feel this is the wrong way around. I'd be in favor of displaying the unicode characters in the JSON view mode (which should be "pretty"), and displaying escape sequences in raw mode.

issue.title: [Snyk] Upgrade classnames from 2.3.1 to 2.3.2

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
Snyk has created this PR to upgrade classnames from 2.3.1 to 2.3.2.

This makes it easier to fix existing vulnerabilities and to more quickly identify and fix newly disclosed vulnerabilities when they affect your project.
